X11 client-side library. Low level ABI.

Example code

Use low level API at your own risk.

# You have to manually import all required definitions.
import pkg/dynlibx11/x11/xinc
import pkg/dynlibx11/x11/xlib
import pkg/dynlibx11/libx11

proc main() =
  # Initialize X11 library. This must be the very first thing to do.
  if not open_x11_library():
    echo "Failed to open X11 library: ", last_x11_error()
    quit QuitFailure
  defer:
    close_x11_library()
  
  # Initialize the display.
  let display = XOpenDisplay nil
  if display == nil:
    echo "Can't connect to X server ", XDisplayName nil
    quit QuitFailure
  defer:
    discard XCloseDisplay display
  
  let screen = XDefaultScreen display
  let root = XRootWindow(display, screen)
  let white = XWhitePixel(display, screen)
  let black = XBlackPixel(display, screen)
  
  # Create the window.
  let window = XCreateSimpleWindow(display, root, 0, 0, 640, 480, 0,
                                   white, black)
  defer:
    discard XDestroyWindow(display, window)
  
  discard XMapWindow(display, window)
  
  discard XSelectInput(display, window,
                       ButtonPressMask or ExposureMask or KeyPressMask)
  
  var event: XEvent
  
  # Event loop.
  while true:
    discard XNextEvent(display, event.addr)
    case event.typ
    of Expose:
      echo "Expose event"
    of ButtonPress:
      echo "Button pressed"
    of KeyPress:
      echo "Key pressed"
    else:
      discard

when isMainModule:
  main()

Imports

x11/xlib, x11/xutil

Procs

proc close_x11_library() {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Close library. 
proc dlerror(): string {....deprecated: "Use last_x11_error instead.", raises: [],
                         tags: [], forbids: [].}
Deprecated: Use last_x11_error instead. 
proc last_x11_error(): string {.inline, ...raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}

Return a human-readable string describing the error that occured from a call to open_name_library() or empty string on no error.

The returned string does not include a trailing newline.

On POSIX it returns:

  • "libname.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory"
  • "/lib/path/libname.so: undefined symbol: foo"

On Windows it returns:

  • "Module not found." -- DLL was not found.
  • "Procedure not found." -- A function/variable was not found in DLL. No additional information is supplied.
proc open_x11_library(): bool {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Open library.
